objtitle.title: Letter to John Linnell, c. April 1827

objdescid.compdate: 1827Keynes (*Letters*, page 168) gives the approximate date of this letter as 1827, placing it in his edition between Blake's letters of 14 March 1827 and 12 April 1827.

objinfo.numberleaves: 1The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. Blake's letter appears on the first recto (object 2) and the address on the second verso (object 1) of the folded sheet. The bottom left corner of the leaf containing object 1 is torn away, leaving part of the other leaf of the folded letter visible behind it in the image of object 1.

provenance.name: Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Yale University
provenance.note: John Linnell; inserted in *Songs of Innocence* (copy Q); sold at Sotheby's, 30 July 1893, as part of lot 1100, including *Songs of Innocence* (copy Q), 28 coloured plates, two coloured drawings by Blake [Butlin #785, ”Timon”], pen and ink signed portrait by John Linnell and "a drawing of the portrait by Schiavonetti" (£49.10s to Heath); acquired by W. A. White, New York; acquired by Alfred W. Van Sinderen; purchased from Van Sinderen by Yale University through the Chauncey Brewster Tinker Fund, 1965; located in Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Yale University.

repository.institution: Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Yale University
repository.repositoryid: GEN MSS 914, Box 1, Folder 8 (formerly MS Vault Shelves Blake)

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. Blake's letter appears on the first recto (object 2) and the address on the second verso (object 1) of the folded sheet. The bottom left corner of the leaf containing object 1 is torn away, leaving part of the other leaf of the folded letter visible behind it in the image of object 1.
Two pencil inscriptions by one or more unknown hands appear on object 1: some illegible wrting to the left of the first line of the address and "(4)" near the tear along the bottom left corner.

desc.objtitle: I am still far from recoverd, Object 2

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. Blake's letter appears on the first recto (object 2) and the address on the second verso (object 1) of the folded sheet. The bottom left corner of the leaf containing object 1 is torn away, leaving part of the other leaf of the folded letter visible behind it in the image of object 1.

lg.l: I am still far from recoverdrecovered
& dare not get out in the cold air. Yet I
lose nothing by it Dante goes on the better
which is all I care about
Mr Butts is to have a Proof Copy
for Three Guineas this is his own decision
quite in Character he calldcalled on me this Week
